title: Dimons are forever: Wall Street's love affair with longstanding CEOs
text:
One scoop to start: the activist hedge fund Bluebell Capital Partners has taken a stake in the pharmaceuticals group GlaxoSmithKline to push for chief executive Emma Walmsley to reapply for her job, backing proposals put forward by fellow investor Elliott Management.

And one event coming up: join us on October 14 at the Business of Sport US Summit for conversations on the future of business in the world's most valuable sports leagues. Wall Street's legion of ‘forever CEOs'

When it comes to CEO succession on Wall Street, the mantra in boardrooms may well be: “If it ain't broke, don't fix it.”

Bank of America's Brian Moynihan signalled earlier this month that he intends to run the US bank until 2030, echoing plans by JPMorgan Chase chief executive Jamie Dimon to extend his tenure to reach at least two decades on the throne. 

Morgan Stanley's James Gorman has also indicated a desire to remain at the helm of the bank he has led since 2010 for at least another three years.

The trio bucks the broader trend in corporate America, where the average tenure of departing chiefs at financial companies within the Russell 3000 index has more than halved, from just under 15 years in 2017 to seven years in 2020, according to data compiled by the research group The Conference Board and the ESG data analytics firm ESGAUGE.

Long tenures hold obvious advantages: banking CEOs who have been in the job for more than a decade amass the knowledge needed to run sprawling institutions often seen as too large to manage.

But then there's the risk that potential successors will grow impatient and leave, as has happened at JPMorgan, where a string of executives slated for the top job have departed in recent years. 

Steve Black and Bill Winters, who ran the investment bank until 2012, left to become co-CEO of Bregal Investments and chief executive of Standard Chartered, respectively. Jes Staley, the sole chief executive of the investment bank for a few years after the duo left, now runs Barclays. 

More recently, JPMorgan's co-chief operating officer Gordon Smith — a top lieutenant of Dimon's — stepped down with Marianne Lake and Jennifer Piepszak taking on the role. 

They've both been named as potential successors to the top job but the process is a slow-moving one with no signs that Dimon will give up his tenure just yet.

Long CEO terms can also serve as a roadblock in the push towards greater diversity among the ranks of chief executives, an area where Wall Street has lagged behind other US companies. 

Banks have tried to compensate for the lack of diversity at the very top by promoting more women to the lower rungs of the C-suite, as evidenced by reshuffles at Bank of America and JPMorgan this year, which handed more responsibility to senior female executives.

In the past decade, though, CEOs at large US banks have rarely stepped down unless they were forced to. Only Goldman Sachs's Lloyd Blankfein decided to leave of his own volition when he handed the reins to David Solomon in 2018 after 12 years in the top job. Picking the right time to go can be a challenge, he told the FT's Joshua Franklin and Imani Moise. 

“When things are going well you don't want to leave but when things are going poorly you feel you can't leave,” Blankfein said. “You have to have discipline to leave when you don't want to leave.”

What a potential restructuring of Evergrande could look like

Yesterday we dove into the liquidity crisis at the Chinese real estate giant Evergrande, which has the potential to spark the biggest debt restructuring in China's history.

Investors were left in the dark this week as to whether the central government would step in to contain the explosion or allow the ailing property developer to fail as a cautionary tale for China's debt-laden real estate sector.

Evergrande offered anxious shareholders and creditors an inkling of faith on Wednesday by announcing it had “resolved” interest payments for an onshore bond due on Thursday.

But the company failed to specify when it would make the payments. It also has a $83.5m payment due on Thursday on its US dollar bonds, which it hasn't yet addressed.

Questions still loom as to what a potential restructuring could look like, many of which the FT's Thomas Hale, Edward White and Sun Yu have addressed in this explainer.

Any measures taken by Beijing to curb collateral economic damage will probably favour Evergrande's onshore bondholders, embittered retail investors and the majority state-owned banks residing within its financial system.

Downplaying fears that the crisis could spread globally, the famed short seller Jim Chanos told the FT he believes China could now be confronting a “far worse” situation within its own borders.

“If you try to deflate this bubble, it is fraught with risks,” he warned. 

A default could ricochet through the broader Asian corporate debt market in a blow to China's property-driven growth model, the rumblings of which have already begun to be felt by the market as domestic banks brace for losses.

As for the yield-hungry offshore bondholders such as Ashmore, BlackRock, UBS and HSBC that boosted their bond holdings in Evergrande ahead of the crisis . . . well, they're just not top priority right now.

Netflix's golden ticket to the Ronald Dahl universe

Much like a stroll through Willy Wonka's chocolate factory, a scroll through Netflix's content library hints at infinite possibility.

By acquiring the works of the late children's author Roald Dahl for about £500m, the streaming giant has procured a golden egg that hatches profits in more ways than one.

Not only will Netflix gain the rights to classics such as Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, Matilda and The Witches, it will also become an “underlying” rights holder with the power to develop Dahl's creations in other formats, promising a “unique universe” across film, television, publishing and more.

The deal is the first of its kind for the video streaming group, which is fighting to defend its position as the world's most popular streaming service against Amazon, HBO, Disney and other rivals in the endless battle for subscribers.

Unlike Amazon, which is buying MGM Studios for $8.45bn, and Disney, which purchased 21st Century Fox for $71bn in 2019, Netflix lacks a studio of its own. Acquiring the Dahl library could be the start of a new strategy to stockpile exclusive content.

The deal is unlikely to generate the kind of pay-off Disney has seen with its $4bn purchase of Marvel in 2009, however, as the FT's Lex column points out, as movie rights to six Dahl works have been licensed out to other studios, leaving Netflix with the production of mostly animated and live-action TV shows.

The Roald Dahl Story Company, which apologised for anti-Semitic comments made by the late author, said a “significant part” of the proceeds would be used to establish a charitable trust that would focus on “children's health, anti-hate and anti-racism”.

Job moves

  • Facebook technology chief Mike Schroepfer will step down next year after 13 years at the company. He will be replaced by longtime Facebook executive Andrew Bosworth.

  • Slaughter and May has elected Deborah Finkle as its first female managing partner. She will take over from practice partner David Wittmann and executive partner Paul Stacey when they retire in May.

  • Nomura has appointed Jeff McDermott as a senior managing director and global co-head of investment banking, based in New York. He was previously joint head of investment banking at UBS before founding Greentech Capital Advisors, which was acquired by Nomura in April last year.

  • Mike Manley, the North America chief executive of Stellantis (formed through a merger of France's PSA and Fiat Chrysler in January) will leave his role on November 1 to become CEO of the Florida-based vehicle retailer AutoNation.

  • Värde Partners has promoted Shannon Gallagher and Mona Girotra to global co-heads of its business development and investor relations group, based in London and New York, respectively.
